Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Group-Transfer Reactions of Low-Coordinate Metals
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) Program, Professor Gregory Hillhouse at the University of Chicago will carry out fundamental studies on the coordination and organometallic chemistry of low-coordinate first-row metals in various oxidation states. The primary objective of this work is to develop synthetic routes to new types of reactive late-transition metal complexes that can be used to carry out new atom- and group-transfer reactions that will enable efficient, atom-economical chemical transformations. These studies will help elucidate fundamental properties of inorganic molecules, particularly those with metal-ligand multiple bonds that stimulate novel reactivity. This chemistry will impact both stoichiometric and catalytic synthetic organic transformations. Group 10 metal complexes have widespread synthetic application in catalytic coupling reactions that form new carbon-carbon (C-C) and C-X single bonds, and this project will focus on developing useful methods for forming C=C, C=N, C=O, and C=S bonds (or other double bonds) utilizing nickel and other first-row metals. This research will explore, using experiment and theory, the coordination and organometallic chemistry of very low-coordinate metal complexes that form multiple bonds with imido and carbene ligands (LnNi=NR and LnNi=CR2), as well as non-traditional 2- and 3-coordinate open-shell, late-metal systems.


This research will provide a solid, fundamental understanding of the chemistry of group transfer reactions involving metals that will impact applied areas of synthetic inorganic chemistry and catalysis, as well as organic synthesis and thus contribute to sustainability. In addition to the scientific contributions, this project will contribute to the training of the next generation of scientists and teachers by providing experience in interdisciplinary work, honing research skills, and exposure to both target-oriented and fundamental research that will empower coworkers to make transformative contributions to US chemical research endeavors. Specific activities directed toward education and outreach, with emphasis on the chemical challenges of the twenty-first century, are planned. The research team will include scientists at all educational levels: faculty, postdoctoral researchers, graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students. Participation of persons from underrepresented groups, which recently have included Hispanic, African-American, sight-disabled, and female coworkers, will be actively encouraged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many large-scale chemical processes are carried out with the aid of transition-metal complexes called catalysts, which mediate the bond-breaking and bond-forming reactions that convert starting materials to products and enable the efficient production of myriad chemicals and materials that are essential for everyday life. This program has probed fundamental aspects of the synthesis, structures, bonding and reactivity of metal complexes that are relevant to catalytic chemistry. The main goal has been to synthesize and probe the reactivity of complexes of nickel and other first-transition-series metals that contain imido (M=NR), amido (M-NR2), sulfide (M-S-M), alkyl (M-R) and thiolate (M-SR) ligands. Complexes with low coordination numbers (2 or 3 ligands) were targeted to favor metal-ligand multiple bonding and promote new reactivity modes. Low-coordinate complexes were successfully synthesized by using sterically bulky N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands. (NHC)Ni imido, alkyl and amido complexes were prepared and their reactions with olefins, alkyl halides and aryl halides were investigated to probe mechanistic issues related to catalytic olefin aziridination and C-C and C-N coupling reactions. (NHC)Cu amido complexes were synthesized and their reactions with carbon dioxide (CO2) were studied, providing insights to potential strategies for the conversion of CO2 to value-added products. The dinuclear complex {(NHC)Ni(μ-S)}2, which contains two bridging sulfide ligands, was prepared and demonstrated to react with hydrogen to generate {(NHC)Ni(μ-SH)}2. A detailed experimental and computational mechanistic study established that this reaction proceeds by heterolytic activation of H2 by a Ni-S bond in the intact {(NHC)Ni(μ-S)}2 dimer. This reaction models a potential H2 activation step in catalytic hydrodesulfurization, the catalytic process used to remove sulfur-containing impurities from petroleum feedstocks and fuels. (NHC)Cu thiolate complexes were generated and demonstrated to undergo facile reactions with alkyl halides to form thioether (R-S-R) products. (NHC)Co amido complexes were synthesized and found to undergo unusual ligand redistribution reactions. The results of this research have been disseminated in the form of peer-reviewed papers and oral presentations at American Chemical Society conferences and universities.

            This project has contributed to the development of human resources in science and technology through the education and mentoring of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, undergraduates and high school students. Students have received rigorous training in organometallic and inorganic chemistry, synthesis, mechanisms, spectroscopic and analytical methods, catalysis, computational chemistry and safety, all of which are important in chemistry and related disciplines. This project has also provided students with opportunities for training in problem-solving strategies, oral and written communication, leadership, ethics and other professional skills. The combination of a broad interdisciplinary knowledge base, cutting-edge research experience, and direct exposure to both target-oriented and fundamental exploratory research gained from participating in this program will enable the students to make significant contributions to the US academic and industrial establishments. The postdoctoral fellows and graduate students who participated in this project have moved on to industrial research and academic positions, and the undergraduates who worked on this project have matriculated in top graduate programs in chemistry.


Last Modified: 05/04/2017
Modified by: Richard F Jordan
